channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: News Analysis: Merkel, While Refusing to Halt Migrant Influx, Works to Limit It
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, who has rejected all requests to limit the influx of newcomers, maintains that it would be a “gigantic mistake” if Germans did not welcome refugees.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel has won the support of German leftists while angering conservatives.

item.title: New Women’s Political Party in Britain Demands Faster Equality
item.description: Weary of delays, a comedian and two journalists have begun the daunting process of forging a party separate from the traditional political power base.
item.dc:creator: SAPHORA SMITH
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandi Toksvig, a founder of the Women's Equality Party in Britain, at an event in London last week.

item.title: Russia Places Sanctions on Turkey
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin on Saturday called for sanctions against Turkey, following the downing this week by Turkey of a Russian warplane.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 4 Egyptian Police Officers Killed Near Cairo in Drive-By Shooting
item.description: Masked gunmen on a motorcycle fired on a security checkpoint. No one has claimed responsibility for the attack.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Mortar Attack on a U.N. Base in Mali Kills at Least 3
item.description: No one claimed responsibility for the attack, which also wounded 20 people, four of whom were in serious condition, a United Nations spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Transgender Argentines Confront Continued Murder and Discrimination
item.description: Recent unsolved killings of transgender women have jolted Argentina, which has introduced some of the most liberal civil rights legislation in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:credit: Anibal Adrian Greco for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrea Cantero, 29, a transgender woman, owns a hair salon in Buenos Aires. “Society hasn’t changed in the slightest,” she said.

item.title: In Spain, New Political Party Makes Gains From Surprising Place — the Center
item.description: The party, Citizens, has expanded its base, shot up in the polls and unseated Spain’s other insurgent party, Podemos, as the rising threat to Spain’s established parties.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Arnau Bach for The New York Times
item.media:description: Albert Rivera, the leader of a new party in Spain called Citizens, giving a television interview recently. The party entered national politics just last year, but is challenging the established order.

item.title: Pope Francis Offers Mass in Uganda at Shrine for Christian Martyrs
item.description: Hundreds of thousands came to see the pope at the Namugongo shrines, which are dedicated to 19th century Christian converts who were killed for refusing to renounce their beliefs.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Ugandans sang and cheered as Pope Francis arrived to celebrate Mass at the Namugongo shrines in Kampala, the capital.

item.title: Prominent Kurdish Lawyer Is Killed in Southeast Turkey
item.description: Tahir Elci, an outspoken human rights lawyer, and a police officer were killed by gunmen after he spoke a news conference in Turkey’s Sur District.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Turkan Elci after her husband, Tahir Elci, an outspoken human rights lawyer, was killed on Saturday in the Sur District.

item.title: Tibetans Fight to Salvage Fading Culture in China
item.description: New measures scaling back the teaching of minority languages like Tibetan have threatened the survival of ethnic identities and traditions in China’s vast West.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Young Tibetan monks during a Tibetan writing class at a monastery.

item.title: Paris Climate Talks Avoid Scientists’ Idea of ‘Carbon Budget’
item.description: Nations have pointedly declined to take up a recommendation from scientists, made several years ago, that they set a cap on total greenhouse gases.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Lu Yang on Art, ‘Uterus Man’ and Living Life on the Web
item.description: The Shanghai-born new media artist has produced a series of boundary-pushing multimedia works that explore neuroscience, mortality and religion.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: A video still from "Moving Gods" by Lu Yang.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: France’s Cult of Fearlessness
item.description: Parisians won’t admit that they go to the gym, let alone that they’re scared of terrorists.
item.dc:creator: PAMELA DRUCKERMAN

item.title: Setsuko Hara, Japanese Star of Films by Ozu and Kurosawa, Is Dead at 95
item.description: Ms. Hara was lauded for her portrayal of tragic heroines torn between duty and desire. Her abrupt retirement in the 1960s shocked Japan.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: Setsuko Hara, center, in “Tokyo Story” (1953), directed by Yasujiro Ozu, with whom she had a 12-year collaboration. Ms. Hara began acting at the age of 15 and retired from film in 1961.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The New Atomic Age We Need
item.description: If we are serious about replacing fossil fuels, we are going to need nuclear power.
item.dc:creator: PETER THIEL

item.title: Cubans Protest Stricter Rules for Traveling to Ecuador
item.description: Cubans crowded outside an Ecuadorean embassy, worried about a new visa requirement to enter Ecuador, a vital step to reach the United States.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: BTG Pactual, Brazilian Bank, Seeks to Calm Investors After C.E.O.’s Arrest
item.description: BTG Pactual, a Brazilian investment bank, has promised to cooperate with any investigation into corruption involving Petrobras.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA and DAN HORCH
item.media:credit: Paulo Fridman for The New York Times
item.media:description: André Esteves, who has been the driving force behind BTG Pactual, is now in jail. The bank's stock has fallen 26 percent since the arrest.

item.title: World Briefing: West Bank: Palestinians Killed After Hit-and-Run Attacks
item.description: The Israeli authorities said troops shot and killed two Palestinians who had rammed their cars into soldiers.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Terrorism Suspects Held After Raids
item.description: The authorities arrested 40 people and put 92 others under house arrest on suspicion that they were militants returning from Syria and Iraq.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Boko Haram Is Suspected as Suicide Bomber Kills 21 Shiites
item.description: The attack occurred during an annual religious procession from Kano, Nigeria’s second-largest city, to Zaria.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
